title: Fuel Tank - Removal

body.body: Warning - General - Stabilise Motorcycle - including DO NOT support on non integral parts
Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
Do not support the motorcycle on any ancillary component, the exhaust system or any other non structural parts of the motorcycle frame.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
An unstable motorcycle may fall resulting in motorcycle damage, serious injury or death.
Observe the warning advice given in the General Information section on the safe handling of fuel and fuel containers.
A fire, causing personal injury and damage to property could result from spilled fuel or fuel not handled or stored correctly.
Never drain fuel from the tank using non-approved fuel handling equipment.
A fire that causes personal injury or destruction of property can result from use of non-approved fuel handling equipment.
Using workshop equipment approved for fuel handling, drain all fuel from the fuel tank.
Remove the fixing that attaches the rear of fuel tank to the frame.

Slightly raise the rear of the fuel tank and move it rearwards to release the locating tab at the front from the rubber locating block. Lift the fuel tank horizontally to gain access to fuel line, breather hoses and electrical connectors.
With the aid of an assistant, disconnect the electrical connector for the fuel pump and the fuel level sensor.
Do not disconnect the fuel hose unless the fuel pressure has been released.
If the fuel hose is disassembled without first releasing the pressure, fuel can escape onto clothing and components.
Escaped fuel is a serious fire hazard that can cause burn injuries and damage to property.
Fuel stored in the fuel rail will be at
. Therefore it is essential that the fuel pressure is reduced before the fuel system is disassembled.
To reduce the pressure, crank the engine momentarily with the fuel pump disconnected.
When disconnected, the fuel tank is self-sealing but a small amount of fuel may leak from the hose.
Get the help of an assistant to reconnect the battery, positive (red) lead first, and crank the engine to reduce pressure in the fuel rail.
Disconnect the battery, negative (black) lead first.
Before disconnection, note the position of the fuel hose, breather and drain hoses so that they can be returned to the same locations when refitting the tank.
Disconnect the fuel hose by squeezing the sides of the connector and pulling the hose free from its spigot on the fuel pump plate.
Release the wire hose clips and disconnect the breather and drain hoses at the inline hose joiners.
Remove the fuel tank from the frame.

Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
Do not support the motorcycle on any ancillary component, the exhaust system or any other non structural parts of the motorcycle frame.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
An unstable motorcycle may fall resulting in motorcycle damage, serious injury or death.
Observe the warning advice given in the General Information section on the safe handling of fuel and fuel containers.
A fire, causing personal injury and damage to property could result from spilled fuel or fuel not handled or stored correctly.
Perform the following operations:
Seat - Removal
Battery - Removal
Never drain fuel from the tank using non-approved fuel handling equipment.
A fire that causes personal injury or destruction of property can result from use of non-approved fuel handling equipment.
Using workshop equipment approved for fuel handling, drain all fuel from the fuel tank.
Remove the fixing that attaches the rear of fuel tank to the frame.
Fuel tank
Bolt
Nut

Slightly raise the rear of the fuel tank and move it rearwards to release the locating tab at the front from the rubber locating block. Lift the fuel tank horizontally to gain access to fuel line, breather hoses and electrical connectors.
With the aid of an assistant, disconnect the electrical connector for the fuel pump and the fuel level sensor.
Fuel hose connector
Electrical connector
Wire hose clip
Breather and drain hoses
Do not disconnect the fuel hose unless the fuel pressure has been released.
If the fuel hose is disassembled without first releasing the pressure, fuel can escape onto clothing and components.
Escaped fuel is a serious fire hazard that can cause burn injuries and damage to property.
Fuel stored in the fuel rail will be at
3.5 bar (350 kpa/50.8 lb/in²)
. Therefore it is essential that the fuel pressure is reduced before the fuel system is disassembled.
To reduce the pressure, crank the engine momentarily with the fuel pump disconnected.
When disconnected, the fuel tank is self-sealing but a small amount of fuel may leak from the hose.
Get the help of an assistant to reconnect the battery, positive (red) lead first, and crank the engine to reduce pressure in the fuel rail.
Disconnect the battery, negative (black) lead first.
Before disconnection, note the position of the fuel hose, breather and drain hoses so that they can be returned to the same locations when refitting the tank.
Disconnect the fuel hose by squeezing the sides of the connector and pulling the hose free from its spigot on the fuel pump plate.
Release the wire hose clips and disconnect the breather and drain hoses at the inline hose joiners.
Remove the fuel tank from the frame.
